comments.text:
+RumbleFish252 Are you suggesting that anything we do that is in any way 
impacted by other people is brainwashing? If you are, this is a weird 
definition of brainwashing, and frankly is one which I am simply unwilling 
to grant.

From Merriam-Webster:

Brainwash:

1:  a forcible indoctrination to induce someone to give up basic political, 
social, or religious beliefs and attitudes and to accept contrasting 
regimented ideas
2:  persuasion by propaganda or salesmanship

I will accept either of these two definitions (though I vastly prefer the 
first, as that is the most common usage, it seems). However, to state that 
anything humans do as a result of peer pressure is brainwashing is 
ridiculous. If this were the case, then everything anyone does *at all* 
would be brainwashed behavior. If you can name me one thing that anyone 
does that is not influenced by what their peers do, please enlighten me.
comments.author: Bryce Pantoja

comments.text:
"Imagine, for instance, that each house had to pay for the maintenance of 
the section for street right in front of it. That would be ridiculous. You 
pay taxes, and the city takes care of it, for the benefit of everyone."  
Yeah, that's how it is supposed to work, but in reality, a contractor does 
the work and the way in which contractors bid for jobs isn't generally 
based upon the quality of their workmanship.  We pay taxes, and the 
city/county gets to it eventually, maybe.  The problem is that we now run 
churches and the government like corporations and we treat corporations 
like people but then don't hold them as accountable.  Who holds the 
government accountable?  I don't trust the US government, which has become 
too corrupt and wound up in red tape, to take care of my health.  When the 
government cannot even manage itself and its own finances any better than I 
can (and I don't lately), why should I trust it with running my health 
care?  If the US were a little smaller in population and the government 
were ran efficiently and honestly, I might consider a single payer plan.  
Right now though, I see no difference between government ran health care 
and health insurance...except that now costs seem to have gone up as we 
took this so-called 'step in the right direction'.
comments.author: Tletna

comments.text:
+AbominableHuman
I think good answer to the problem is this: 1) When someone buys a gun in 
the US, do a background check in case they're nuts and/or violent, maybe 
via a license. 2)Make it so guns are kept securely, so no one can randomly 
pick one up and either accidentally or deliberately harm someone. 3)Define 
what guns are suitable for self and home defense and sporting activities 
and limit citizens to that: eg a handgun or a sports shotgun is good to 
defend yourself or go sports shooting, a machine-gun isn't. 4)Maybe 
restrict the amount of guns and ammunition you can have at any one time: 
make it large enough to be fair to those who may shoot regularly like 
sportsmen or huntsmen but small enough to prevent quick build up of 
personal armories.
Can't think of anything else at the moment, but these things should allow 
US citizens to retain their right to bare arms as they currently have it, 
whilst putting some restrictions to try lessen the number of crazy people 
running around with loads of guns.
Don't try to take all guns away, but don't let everyone have them either. 
Not everyone can mentally handle having a weapon and not everyone is 
mentally sound enough to have access to one......

comments.text:
+AbominableHuman 
You're more likely to kill yourself, your loved ones, or damage your 
property with your guns than an intruder. 

I don't think we have ever seen a democrat in any position of power try to 
takeaway your guns nor a strong movement to, it's a strawman. No one with a 
brain would try to take guns away from a country with such a strong 
disgusting gun culture because we'd have a (failed) rebellion on our hands  

There's a difference between gun prohibition and drug prohibition.  If I 
smoke a joint or drink alcohol the only one at any risk if I'm not driving 
is myself, and that is certainly not the purpose. A gun is a weapon, that's 
all it's for, its only point is damage. There need to be standards for 
that.  You should need a license to own a gun,  you should need to undergo 
some sort of psychiatric evaluation and a criminal background check.  That 
is the most extreme position I have ever heard out of anyone.  And it 
likely wouldn't even really be unconstitutional "A WELL REGULATED militia 
being necessary to the security of a free state," is how the second 
amendment starts off, I say if your goal is to create a militia, and you're 
regulating it, you should probably regulate the mentally unstable and 
violent criminals out of said militia, and it wouldn't be that unreasonable 
to make sure they know how to use the weapon they'd apparently use as a 
militia soldier.

There is also a prohibition on driving without a license.  Does anyone 
consider that a failed prohibition? I mean I' sure some people drive 
without a license, but in general people don't. And there's an actual 
practical reason to own a car, a gun for self defense is often just 
decreasing your safety from yourself to sate your paranoia of others 
invading your home.

comments.text:
Communism doesn't imply atheism. Marxism does, but that's not the only form 
of communism, just the most well known. The early Christian communities 
were communist and certainly not atheist.

Besides that, North Korea doesn't claim to be communist. A form of 
communism was a part of their founding ideals and there may be some 
practices left, but they revised their constitution and removed the 
references to communism (
http://www.reuters.com/article/2009/09/28/idUSSEO253213). Modern communist 
states aren't really communist. They're meant to be a socialist 
transitional state to eventually get to stateless communism. None ever seem 
to really try to make the transition happen. North Korea gave up the 
pretense.

comments.text:
"Primal causation". Interesting exercise in logic came up originally by 
Thomas Aquinas. Look in the sky, and see a cloud. Where did it come from? 
Dust and water vapor. Where did the dust and water vapor come from? Smashed 
rocks and oceanic evaporation. So where did the rocks and water come from? 
Eventually you get to stellar material being flung out into the cosmos. And 
where did this stellar material come from? It takes a lot more faith to 
believe in the Quantum Mechanics idea that matter can spontaneously form 
out of nothing than it does to believe in God. Who, by the way, isn't an 
"invisible sky person", but rather the causation of existence. God is 
existence. God is in you, God is in the cloud, God is in everything and 
beyond. Since the universe doesn't benefit God in any way, it's logical to 
assume that the motive for creation is love--a beneficence which must 
express itself beyond oneself. Hell, by the way, is simply "heaven" for 
those who reject God's love. God doesn't send anyone to hell. People send 
themselves to hell. People gravitate towards that which they venerate. If 
you only venerate yourself or the pleasure this world gives you at the 
expense of others, then you reject the reality of why you exist.

comments.text:
+Fern Sinclair I am in Canada. The area I am in, was much more old 
fashioned too than most areas of Canada. The area I was in, was more 
Catholic, so kids were generally expected to take religion classes and 
attend church during school hours, and some, including me, ended up being 
altar boys.

It is similar to how people say a 'good' girl, at least in my area, wears 
longer clothes, wears no make up and does not talk obnoxiously etc. Except 
for boys, a boy was considered 'good' if he joined Cadets, Scouts or other 
similar activities as a way to show their dedication to their community.

Until the late 90's, corporal punishment was used in my schools for boys 
who acted up. In the province just a few minutes from where I was living, 
was more diversified, so as a result, when I moved there, kids were not 
spanked and slapped with rulers, but kids there did vandalise schools and 
neighbourhoods more than they did in the other province.
comments.author: David Frigault

comments.text:

American boy scouts. It's sad because nowadays it's almost socially 
embarrassing to be a part of it. But I find it to be such a good program, 
minus the God aspect of it (the older one basically has to hide the fact 
that he's a staunch atheist). It really teaches boys such good leadership 
skills, respect, etc etc etc. And it teaches kids how to handle a gun 
PROPERLY... Something people in the US are obviously lacking.

+MosbeckSB  You're basically preaching to the choir. I'm not arguing at all 
that Americans aren't brainwashed -- I'm saying that it's a different sort 
of brainwashing than is experienced in NK. It's definitely more dangerous, 
as history has shown. This mentality has basically led us to rape the 
entire world. It's actually quite disillusioning. This 
capitalist/consumerist attitude it like a disease, and it's spreading 
across the world, destroying economies and lives as it goes. The worst part 
is that I don't see any solution until a couple hundred years from now when 
the system potentially collapses upon itself. When people finally become so 
disillusioned and understand that there's no empirical evidence to support 
the Laissez Faire model.

comments.text:
+Alexisthebest ever "If you do somehow successfully attack North Korea, 
China would strike back at America in revenge of their ally."
I believe you are spot-on, except for China attacking the US.
China does not want North Korea to fall for the sole reason that (even 
though North Korea is far more 'extreme' than China) North Korea acts as a 
buffer and allows China to effectively isolate itself.
However, as the world is beginning to look like (and arguably already looks 
like), China no longer wishes to isolate itself/ is heading down that path.
So if China had a 'reset' button, I'm fairly sure that if not now, then 
some time in the very near future, China would chose for North Korea to not 
be there at all (but they would still have the same problem that the 
US/west has, wishing something isn't there is a lot different than it not 
being there).

And further to the point, I don't think China would willfully put itself on 
the opposite side against the US. Sure, it might threaten, possibly to 
re-assure its more extreme allies (as is the case with Russia), but if it 
actually came down to it, this isn't the 1950s, China and the US are 
intermingled, and it would hurt China for multiple reasons to fight US 
forces not interfering with China:
1) It could lead to a US/China war, in which China has a very real 
possibility of losing, or at least losing face.
2) If economic ties were broken off, it would hurt China considerably more 
than the US, which suddenly doesn't have to pay multiple trillions of 
dollars.

I think the issue here is that I responded initially to your statement 
about what your perception of progressivism is. I in turn, was put off by 
the implication of brain-washing that you surmise is part and parcel of 
progressive ideology. I will tell you first off, I am not an ideologue, nor 
a member of that school of thought. I believe firmly in the principle of 
individual liberty, though my politics tend to coincide with some of the 
same principles found within the progressive philosophy. The issue here is 
perception. You perceive modern progressives to be hearkening to those 
movements of the past, when in actualitty the platforms have changed. The 
intentions have not. Progressivism isn't about sacrificing power to the 
state, it is however acknowledgement  of the possibility of a world where 
humans, driven by altruism, have a central regulatory body, that can 
administrate the collective will of the nation, in a fair and just manner. 
prgressiveism tends to be a zeitgeist, because the definition of progress 
changes, as the world moves forward/backward. The platforms are ever 
changing on account of this.

comments.text:
+mweibleii Good to know that you get it then. Now if only we had about 
another 150 million intelligent people like you in society, we might not 
have the problems we have these days.

Oh and by the way, spanking shouldn't be illegal per se', but restricted to 
open palm across butt. That way, as a parent, when administering 
discipline, you have more control over how hard you swat the child's 
bottom. Using a belt or anything else and it is impossible to tell if 
you're disciplining the child, or just plain hurting them. Dr. Spock's 
methods do not work. I've seen this first hand. My mother tested my butt as 
the "Seat of Knowledge" plenty of times and I am a better person for it. 
However my father believed in beating a child senseless, as he did with me 
on many occasions. So yes I do know the "Difference" between proper 
discipline, and improper discipline. To many parents these days let their 
children get away with way too much and we have a great deal of "Wild ones" 
amongst our collective youth these days. Open palm across butt at least 
allows a parent to feel how hard they're hitting their child. If you are 
hurting your own hand, you are hitting them way too hard. Discipline,.. but 
in moderation. No discipline at all has its vices as well,... obvious 
vices. Too much discipline results in bullying as the child can easily feel 
that they are being bullied. I know this first hand. Plus a young man I 
once knew was quite the nasty bully in school. One day I followed him home 
in secret with my friend. We planned on "teaching" him a lesson for picking 
on us. That's when we got to see how his father treated him. Needless to 
say, we told our parents. The Department of Children and Families was 
called as a result. Three months later we saw him at school again. What 
shocked me the most was he thanked us for getting him out of that hell. I 
guess it was a nice surprise.

I believe in moderate discipline, not flat out beating a child. No child 
should have to go through that. But the worst sort of abuse isn't spanking. 
No, verbal abuse can be far worse. Words can cut like steel. Example, I 
don't remember every instance when my father beat me, but I do recall damn 
near every nasty thing he ever said to me. And trust me, it was a lot. Sad 
to say, but if he died tomorrow, it wouldn't matter to me. My mother on the 
other hand, that would affect me real bad. I have many many memories of the 
supportive and caring things she ever said to me. She spanked me when I 
stepped out of line. She disciplined me when I screwed up, but with her, I 
understood "why". And that is the key word here. If the child doesn't 
understand why, spanking, beating, or grounding, etc. makes little 
difference.
comments.author: Michael0075

likely that the point of impact would have been at a window opening, so the 
combined weight of that aircraft and the speed at which it hit, is more 
than enough to part/widen that steel frame and in milliseconds to pass 
inside and explode.....

The resultant fire from a full load of fuel, allowed the steel frame to be 
subjected to immense temperatures, that softened it to a point that it was 
no longer able to support the considerable weight of the floors above.--You 
will of course have observed that Tower 2 came down first, primarily as it 
was hit lower down and, Tower 1 succumbed a bit later, as it was hit higher 
up, although it was struck first.--Once on the move, that weight smashing 
into successive floors below, was  enough to increase the weight 
exponentially as it fell.--WTC, building 7, was demolished, as 
it was thought to become a risk to rescue personnel......

comments.text:
+tigerspirit1917 Here, you, your children, and your children's children 
can't be imprisoned in hard labor camps for simply disagreeing with " The 
Great Leader".

Here, we don't called our leader Dear Leader, King, father, God, His/Her 
majesty, His excellency. Instead we simply call our leader Mr. President.

Here you won't be arrested for having a "western" hairstyle.

Here, while drugs are still illegal, you wont be executed for just having 
them, let alone using them. 

Here, you wont be executed for possessing or looking at pornography. 

Here, we have a great many number of media and news outlets to choose from 
to get our information about the world, not one single state controlled 
channel. 

Here, you don't have to be a government official in order to own a vehicle. 

Here, while the Founders are dearly respected by many, we are not made to 
literally bow down to giant gold statues of them. Nor hang pictures of them 
in every public or private place and room. Nor utter there names with a 
level of reference that most would reserve only for gods and goddesses. Nor 
be expected to cry hysterically when they die. 

Here, we can read anybook we want, regardless of how "subversive" theyc an 
be to the cultures and goals of our nation. We can freely buy and read 
books like the Communist Manifesto, The Anarchist Cookbook, and Mein Kampf 
if we want to. 

Here, we can wear any kind of clothing we desire. 

Here, we can follow any religion we please, or none at all, without 
constant government checks to ensure we're not promoting any ideas that 
would lessen the government's power over people's lives. 

Here, we can freely move from one part of the country to the next and live 
in whatever city we want without applying for government permission.

We can own a firearm providing we are not felons. 

We can be against capitalism even though we are in a mostly capitalist 
nation without fear of imprisonment or violent repercussions. 

We do recieve propaganda. The big difference is we have the right to 
question it and even just not listen to it. We have the right to speak out 
against it in public, online, and in various publications. 

Can you, as a citizen of the "Democratic" Republic of Korean do any of the 
things I just listed?

No, you can't.

One Reason why I am Roman Catholic is because I acknowledged that the bible

comments.text:
+mbank2 Although I cannot answer on his behalf I'll give you my full 
detailed reason why I'm Roman Catholic. Long Long 2-3 post story incoming.

Part 1 - Everybody makes BS claims to prove the other wrong.

First off, this has to be said. The "evidence" or lack thereof on both 
sides of the argument are generally worded to sound perfect but in some 
cases are completely missing the point or reasons why the other side 
believes in what they believe. Both parties often misunderstand each other 
and that leads to people never believing the other side.

For example, on the religious side it has been decided among HISTORIANS 
that Jesus existed, had a following, was killed by Romans, and who's body 
went missing (resurrection to surreal to be proven with history). Period. 
Was he a magic man who did miracles? No idea but naturally one would think 
no. Many atheists have been bred by Dawkins/Hitchens or people like them to 
believe that Jesus was made up using incorrect reasoning like "oh the bible 
was written 30-60 years after Jesus so he is a fake" or "Taticus is a hoax 
don't listen" (even though he was a pagan Roman historian so there 
shouldn't be a bias) . Those allegations simply misunderstand history and 
how historians track the lives of people in the past. For example, 
Confucius (a Chinese Religious figure) has no writings during his lifetime 
as well but is also considered by historians to be legitimate due to the 
writings afterwards and other proofs.

On the Atheist side evolution has literally NOTHING to do with religion and 
any arguments saying it is false is stupid. In fact they never cross paths 
ever and a lack of belief in God does not correlate to an automatic worship 
of Darwin. Yet Christians still throw this "its just a theory" in some sad 
attempt to make Atheists look bad. I for one think this is stupid simply 
because if even the Catholic Church accepts evolution as fact, nobody 
should be allowed to argue. Though naturally, God is involved but don't 
take what they say the wrong way they basically say it doesn't interfere 
with religion.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catholic_Church_and_evolution

In fact, science in almost all aspects has no correlation with religion and 
yet both sides of the argument try to use science as "proof". Really, it 
all comes down to whether you believe in the bible or not, in terms of 
Christ of course.

Finally, if there is 0 proof god exists and also 0 proof he doesn't, that 
doesn't say anything at all for either side. The score is 0-0. Atheists 
like to spin that saying then there's no point in believing since there's 
not even a chance. Christians spin that saying since you cannot disprove 
him in any regard, he has made himself unbeatable which is one of his 
qualities so therefore he wins and exists. See the problem? The fact 
answers nothing yet both try to use it only under their light.

insist only your biased view is true.  Ignorance is something you clearly 
understand intimately.
comments.author: DeadlyChinchilla

comments.text:
+DeadlyChinchilla Seriously pick up a book and read up on what pragmatism 
is. Granted South Korea has been negatively impacted, but when I said "most 
other people have not been directly or indirectly impacted by North Korea 
in a negative way", the use of the word "most" was granting the notion that 
some harm has been done to some peoples.

The Japanese haven't been harmed by North Korea in recent history, in fact 
it's quite the opposite; the Japanese initiated mass rape and murder of 
millions of Chinese and Korean civilians around the time of the first and 
second Sino-Japanese Wars. 

China also hasn't been harmed by North Korea.

So once again, the only people who've been negatively impacted by North 
Korea are South Koreans. The rest of the world has not been negatively 
impacted. Most people are not affected by North Korea's Government, however 
awful it may be. The same can't be said about America, or any other major 
power in the world. That's quite literally what pragmatism is. Your 
profound ignorance amazes me. Unsurprisingly you had to resort to strawman 
fallacies and argumentum ad misericordium type arguments to make your 
point, yet you claim that I am the "biased" one, even though I'm speaking 
in strictly objective numbers; the amount of people harmed. Yet you insist 
on arguing a subjective misericordium point of view of "oh look how sad the 
south koreans are" as if that is unbiased. I'm talking strictly about the 
number of people, and you're talking about the subjective views of 
relatively few, yet you claim that I am the biased one. Subjective = 
biased, objective = unbiased. Pick up a textbook, your ignorance is sad.
comments.author: Vinh Vu

comments.text:
+Helghastl33t
An invasion of people who are brainwashed into thinking their leaders are 
gods.  The casualties would be entirely made up of the innocent North 
Koreans you would profess we "save."  We would end up KILLING more than we 
saved, because every last one of them is raised hating us, thinking we want 
to take what they have and enslave them.  They would fight to the last 
citizen if we invaded, it would be a massecre of epic proportions.  That 
would be BEFORE the NK army lets loose with whatever missiles it has 
(ineffective as they may be, they still have them).

Sometimes you can't save everyone.  Sometimes they really do have to save 
themselves.
comments.author: DeadlyChinchilla

comments.text:
+Vinh Vu
Talk about an ignorance of pragmatism.  Go ask South Korea how North Korea 
has apparently "not impacted" them.  Ask the Asianic nations in the area in 
general.  Ask Japan.  Ask China what its policies on NK immigration are.  
Your bias becomes far more clear if you can say North Korea doesn't impact 
the rest of the world with a straight face.
comments.author: DeadlyChinchilla

comments.text:
+tomatodamashi
At this point it's the only moral thing to do. It would be costly for sure, 
but running nazi style concentration camps should be an invasion worthy 
offence if we are to consider ourselves moral people.
comments.author: Helghastl33t

comments.text:
+DeadlyChinchilla first off, that's not a bias. America was used as the 
example because tyt is American and reminiscible used it as his example 
first. I was just responding to his example. Secondly, the fact that other 
countries have also done great harm is exactly the point that was made. As 
I said, it's easy to judge a country harshly when you ignore the wrongs 
your own country has done. That's called ethnocentrism and is literally a 
bias to judge north Korea from an American perspective. 

Also you demonstrate an ignorance of what pragmatism is. Pragmatism is in 
essence dealing with things in a practical way. The harm that north Korea 
has done to its people, however bad it may be, does not affect the rest of 
the world. The harm America has done does affect the rest of the world, and 
that's seen in many of the problems in the middle East today, or in parts 
of Asia, and even in parts of America. Sure you can argue that morally, 
North Korea is a more "evil" or brutish place, but pragmatically they have 
done less harm to the world. Practically speaking I am not, and most other 
people have not been directly or indirectly impacted by North Korea in a 
negative way, while we have been by America. ﻿America was used not because 
of any personal bias of mine, but because reminiscible brought it up. Had 
Britain or any other country been used I would have said the same, except 
maybe Canada and Australia cause they haven't had much opportunity to do 
much harm in the world.
comments.author: Vinh Vu

comments.text:
+Vinh Vu
Therein lies your bias.  America is not the only nation on the planet that 
has harmed indigenous peoples.  EVERY major nation and power in HISTORY has 
done that.  You could call Britain the biggest mass murderer on the planet, 
they were offing entire cultures long before the US existed.  But we don't 
hear that because it isn't POPULAR to hate on Britain.

It is not pragmatic to make ridiculous comparisons based only on your 
personal bias for or against a nation.  In terms of harm caused to their 
own people, North Korea is one of the most brutal regimes to exist, EVER, 
on the planet and in history.  Saying NK has done "less harm than America" 
is frankly absurd.
comments.author: DeadlyChinchilla

comments.text:
+Michael Duer He's being pragmatic, and in a sense he has a point. North 
Korea has done less harm to the world in the past few hundred years than 
America has. It's easy to judge them negatively and ignore all the wrongs 
that America had done to basically every ethnic group to set foot on 
American soil.
comments.author: Vinh Vu

comments.text: +Reminiscable you should google availability bias.
comments.author: Supdude1432

comments.text:
+Reminiscable
You either have no idea what life in North Korea is like for the vast 
majority of its citizens, or you're so blinded by your personal political 
opinions (and apparent anti-American attitude) that you are incapable of 
making and judging priorities.  EVERY nation on the planet has done some 
things that were wrong.  There are far more evil places than the US, and 
the US has done a hell of a lot of good as well.  North Korea is probably 
one of the most vile places on the planet, and has systematically decimated 
its own people for well over 50 years.  Not LIKING the USA and saying its 
worse than that is really just ridiculous.
comments.author: DeadlyChinchilla

comments.text:
+Reminiscable you MUST be N. Korean, or just a complete idiot(or possibly 
both) tio actually believe that!! Wow!!
comments.author: Michael Duer

comments.text:
Not to mention they have China fully backing them. A war with china would 
be wholly devistating.
comments.author: Virginia Treichler

comments.text: +Reminiscable youre a clown
comments.author: blistified

comments.text:
Calm down. You live in a country that's done way more wrongs than North 
Korea can and will ever do. Humans naturally follow authorities blindly. If 
they can do so with a sense of purpose then all the better for them. North 
Korea has - you can't even compare - a lot less blood on their hands than 
the US.
comments.author: Reminiscable

comments.text:
+SuperSaiyanMaze
Yeah I understand the desire to do "something" but attacking them would 
only punish the poor civilians (you can't kill them to save them, Iraq and 
Vietnam proved that). Even economic sanctions only hurt the civilians. 
Truth is most measures just hurt the people at the bottom, I guess hoping 
they would uprise or put pressure on the government to change. But in 
highly militarized, authoritarian governments those revolts will just get 
squashed. There really isn't a whole lot we can do.

Look at Cuba (nowhere near as bad as North Korea). America took the change 
or be rejected approach, whereas Canada took the change if you want and we 
will help you approach. The Canadian approach is a lot more patient and 
understanding. Show North Korea what they are passing up and apply passive 
pressure on them. It may take longer, but it is a lot less bloody.

Bottomline: IF we were to invade North Korea, nukes WILL be sent to South 
Korea. Not good for anybody.
comments.author: tomatodamashi

comments.text:
+SuperSaiyanMaze I think having an entirely corrupt and disgusting country 
existing on a section of the planet much better than a larger area of the 
planet being drenched in radiation and blood from the war that will ensue 
in the attempt to hinder the prior.
comments.author: Supdude1432

top_comment.text:
I had wondered why no one had invaded North Korea before they finished 
building there nuclear weapons. The excuse was they had no idea it was 
being built. Now I realise, no one wants to fight 1 million brainwashed 
people who believe the one they fight for can read minds. One delusional 
person can be hard to deal with, imagine 1 million with military training. 
wow.﻿
top_comment.author: fly4life

comments.text:
+Jeff Moe That's if the army members are not being fed. N. Korea don't feed 
their civilians, but they make sure that the army is well fed.
comments.author: essvee86

comments.text:
+essvee86 Numbers of people mean very little if you can't feed 
them...Remember what happened to Saddam Hussein's Elite Guard in Baghdad? 
They ran or surrendered, due to being hungry and tortured by their 
"fearless leader"...
comments.author: Jeff Moe

comments.text:
Because they got the 4th largest army in the world. It won't be a piece of 
cake.

comments.text: That is christian America!!
